p: Even when considering the understory alone, we did not find a difference in foraging success among the three habitat conditions for the Warbler Finch. Although the manual and chemical control of R. niveus in the ‘recently controlled’ area removed the understory, it left dead plant structures behind. We observed many birds using these dead plant structures as foraging substrates. The ‘recently controlled’ area offered many open patches with direct sun exposure for thermophilic arthropods. Additionally, flying insects like moths are known for their dispersal ability in search for new feeding grounds and/or reproduction sites (Young 1997; Dettner and Peters 2011), and hence are capable of rapidly recolonizing recently controlled areas.
